msItem.author: Avienus
msItem.title: Aratea
msItem.rubric: Rufi festi Arati incipit liber primus de positione syderum
msItem.incipit: Carminis incentor mihi iuppiter aussice (corrected to: auspice) terras
msItem.note: no glosses; f. 1r. before v. 76 on the bears heading ARCTOE, ENGONAIs BEFORE v. 169 and so on for each constellation then on f. 5v PLANETAE and CIRCULI, on f. 8v SOL; a second hand wrote on part of f. 1v.;
msItem.filiation: Milan, Biblioteca Ambrosiana, Ms D 52 is a copy of this MS.

msItem.incipit: Ac uirtute uelint patriam defendere terram
msItem.explicit: ad scopullum spaclo (for spacio ?) etatis defensa uetusto.
msItem.finalRubric: Titi Lucretii Cari de rerum natura liber II explicit.

msItem.incipit: O tenebris tantis tam (corrected) clarum extollere lumen

msItem.note: After a rubrication that is almost completely erased begins a section from Book II (vv. 757-805)
msItem.incipit: Praeterea si nulla coloris principiis est
Fundatum ualidis aptum per uiscera neruis
msItem.explicit: non erat ut fieri posset mirarier umquam.

msItem.note: Book I (vv. 734-785 skipped in Copenhagen Kongelige Bibliotek, Gl. Kgl. S. 211 2°, f. 5ra)
msItem.incipit: Hic tamen et supra quo diximus inferiores
msItem.explicit: ex igni retroque in terram cuncta reverti.

msItem.note: Book II (vv. 253-304 skipped in Copenhagen Kongelige Bibliotek, Gl. Kgl. S. 211 2°, f. 8ra)
msItem.explicit: Nam neque quo poscit genus ullum materia.

msItem.note: The entire left column and about two-thirds of the right one are left blank.

msItem.incipit: Semper ego auditor tantum numque reponam
msItem.explicit: Quorum flamina legitur cinis atque latina.

msItem.incipit: Ultra sauromatas fugere hinc libet et glacialem

msItem.explicit: auditor gelidos ueniam caligatus in agros.

msItem.incipit: Ecce iterum crispinus et est mihi saepe uocandus
msItem.explicit: Ceperat hoc nocuit lamiarum cede madenti.

msItem.incipit: Si te propositi nondum pudet adque eadem est mens
msItem.explicit: proxima nec patimur tirrenum crescere piscem.

condition.p: Probably lost a couple of leaves after f.8 with the rest of the poem (missing 297 verses, which could fit around two folios). The eight folia preserved in Copenhagen Kongelige Bibliotek, Gl. Kgl. S. 211 2° preceeded once the second quire. Gap between the second and third preserved quires - between ff. 14 and 15.

layoutDesc.layout: 1r-8v written in two columns, ruled 47 partly irregular lines; at some instances two verses written in the space of one ruler line, with up to 55 written lines; initials for verses detached from the verse; texts occpupies almost the whole length of the page.

history.origin: The two excerpts from Lucretius' text represent two parts from a codex discissus spread in three parts. The other part is the so-called Schedae Gottorpienses fragment with shelfmark Copenhagen Kongelige Bibliotek, Gl. Kgl. S. 211 2° (see Jörgensen, Ellen.Catalogus codicum latinorum medii aevi Bibliothecae Regiae Hafniensis. Hafniae: Gyldendal, 1926, p.301-2). It consists of a gathering of eight folia written in two columns and about 48 verses per page with the text of Book 1 (omitting vv. 734-785) and Book 2 (omitting vv. 253-304). Note the shelfmark there on f. 1r "Q 4784" and the one in the manuscript in Vienna on f. 22v "P 4658". The Copenhagen manuscripts contains Lucretius' De rerum natura Book 1 and 2 (vv. 1-456); some sections skipped there are added in the Vienna manuscripts (see content above). According to Bischoff the script is from s. IX2 . The origin of the manuscript is less certain. Lehmann suggested that it was produced in Bobbio. Bischoff after first considering it as product of Southern Germany ( Lorsch im Spiegel seiner Handschriften, p. 74, No. 30) later agreed with Lehmann's opinion ( Bischoff, Katalog I, p. 88 as well as in the second edition of Lorsch im Spiegel seiner Handschriften, p. 80, No. 30.). Munk Olsen follows this proposition. Due to the quite different script in the third part (ff. 15-22) there were still some doubts if this part too belonged to the codex discissus. Thinking it would have been to much of a coincedence that the poem was copied twice in the same period and both parts ended as part of one and the same codex in the National Library of Vienna deminishes these doubts (see Munk Olsen, L’ étude 4,2, p. 20-1).
history.provenance: In the second half od the 16th c. the manuscript belonged the library of the humanist Wolfgang Lazius (b. 1514 in Vienna d. 1565), as attested by the shelfmark "D" on f. 1r. Lazius worked as court historian and visited many monastic libraries in search for material and sources for his historical monographs. We know of three journeies he made; the third one in 1551 led him among other places also in in the Cistercian monastery in Salem near the Bodensee. Trenkler believed that Cod. 107 was given to Lazius as a gift there, for according to him the "Acta monasterii Salem" were part of the same binding (Trenkler p. 200). After Lazius death his book collection became part of the court library in Vienna, as mentioned by Peter Lambeck (Commentariorum de Augustissima Bibliotheca Caesarea Vindobonensi, Lib. 1, Vienna, 1665, p. 38).

listBibl.bibl: Bischoff, Die Abtei Lorsch im Spiegel ihrer Handschriften. Lorsch: Laurissa, 1989, p. 74.
Trenkler, Ernst. "Wolfgang Lazius, Humanist und Büchersammler." Biblos 27 (1978): 186-203.
